channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Covid Tests and Quarantines: Colleges Brace for an Uncertain Fall
item.description: Colleges are racing to reconfigure dorms, expand testing programs and establish detailed social distancing rules. And then, what to do about sex?
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times
item.media:description: Temporary classrooms on Tulane University's campus in New Orleans are meant to encourage social distancing.

item.title: Florida’s Summer of Dread
item.description: The coronavirus had entrenched itself in communities from Pensacola to Key West, killing more than 7,000 Floridians. Then came Tropical Storm Isaias.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A closed beach in Miami Beach. Between the virus and storms, some Floridians have crisis exhaustion.

item.title: Tropical Storm Isaias, Grazing Florida, Takes Aim at Carolinas
item.description: The Florida coast was spared severe damage on Sunday, but much of the Eastern Seaboard is threatened with flooding rains.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Rebecca Halleck
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winds whipped Palm Beach, Fla., on Sunday, but Tropical Storm Isaias remained offshore and did not deliver the punch officials had feared.

item.title: As Federal Agents Retreat in Portland, Protesters Return to Original Foe: Local Police
item.description: While protests around the federal courthouse have remained calm for three consecutive nights, Portland police officers chased demonstrators through the streets near a local precinct.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Portland police officers disperse protesters who had gathered at the county sheriff’s office on Saturday.

item.title: Navy Investigates Video of Dogs Attacking Man in Kaepernick Jersey
item.description: The Navy condemned the video, which it said was taken at an “independent organization’s event” last year. A filmmaker said it took place at a museum dedicated to the SEALs.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tony Avelar/Associated Press
item.media:description: The quarterback Colin Kaepernick began kneeling during the national anthem to protest racism and police violence in 2016. The gesture has since been adopted by protesters around the country.

item.title: John Eric Swing, a Filipino-American Community Builder, Dies at 48.
item.description: Mr. Swing was a catalyst in the Historic Filipinotown neighborhood of Los Angeles, a new center of food start-ups. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: Isaias Live Updates: Carolinas Brace for Hurricane
item.description: Tropical Storm Isaias is forecast to become a Category 1 hurricane again and make landfall in the Carolinas on Monday. Flash flooding and tornadoes are possible.
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tropical Storm Isaias generated dangerous surf as it moved along Florida’s east coast near Palm Beach on Sunday.

item.title: The 1918 Flu, Masks and Lessons for the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: As the influenza pandemic swept across the United States in 1918 and 1919, masks took a role in political and cultural wars.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Hamilton Henry Dobbin, via California State Library
item.media:description: People waiting for masks in San Francisco in 1918.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: Confirmed Cases in Modoc County
item.description: Monday: The virus found its way into tiny, remote Modoc County. Also: The Apple Fire prompted evacuations, and a successful astronaut return.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Scott Sonner/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Brass Rail, a bar and restaurant in Alturas. An owner said a waitress who worked at the bar tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Biden vs. Trump Live Updates: 2020 Election and Vice President Race
item.description: Joe Biden is making a new effort to challenge President Trump in Ohio. After pulling its television ads to reassess its strategy, the Trump campaign has returned to the airwaves.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Will Congress Act on Covid Soon? ‘I’m Not Optimistic’
item.description: Money for the Postal Service and mail voting is one sticking point: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: What Has Changed Since George Floyd
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police during roll call at the Central Patrol Division for the third and fourth districts in St. Louis last year.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates
item.description: Some U.S. schools begin to reopen with fraught results. With a focus on the coronavirus, other deadly diseases are making a comeback.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump shows a map of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States during an executive order signing ceremony on hiring Americans at the White House on Monday.

item.title: These Conservatives Have a Laser Focus: ‘Owning the Libs’
item.description: On The Federalist and in Fox News appearances, some of President Trump’s supporters don’t really defend him. They attack the critics.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Gage Skidmore
item.media:description: Conservative writers and pundits like Mollie Hemingway of The Federalist spend their time attacking President Trump’s rivals rather than explaining his latest folly.

item.title: A Vast Racial Gap in Death Penalty Cases, New Study Finds
item.description: Defendants convicted of killing white people, the study found, were far more likely to be executed than the killers of Black people.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Abolitionist Action Committee participated in an annual protest and hunger strike against the death penalty outside the Supreme Court last year.

item.title: A Historic Supreme Court Ruling Upends Courts in Oklahoma
item.description: Local prosecutors are referring criminal cases to the federal and tribal courts, which are now flooded with new cases.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

item.title: A Hospital Forgot to Bill Her Coronavirus Test. It Cost Her $1,980.
item.description: Send us your medical bills. We’ll use them to investigate hospital and doctor billing practices.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms/The New York Times
item.media:description: Debbie Krebs felt sick in March and went for a coronavirus test. She tested negative, but then the test was omitted from her medical bill, resulting in a major price difference.

item.title: One-Third of New York’s Small Businesses May Be Gone Forever
item.description: Small-business owners said they have exhausted federal and local assistance and see no end in sight after months of sharp revenue drops. Now, many are closing their shops and restaurants for good.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Amr Alfiky/The New York Times
item.media:description: William Garfield, the owner of Glady’s, a Caribbean restaurant in Brooklyn, said he decided to close after his landlord told him he would need to start paying his full monthly rent.

item.title: Is Telemedicine Here to Stay?
item.description: The answer largely depends on whether Medicare and private health insurers will adequately cover virtual doctor visits once coronavirus outbreaks subside.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: While David Collins of Houston appreciates the ease of telemedicine, he sometimes prefers an in-person doctor’s visit. “If you break your arm, an e-visit isn’t going to help you at all,” he said.

item.title: Trump Pick for Pentagon Post Sidesteps Senate Ire for Different Defense Job
item.description: A retired Army general whose inflammatory comments appeared to doom his nomination was tapped for a job that does not require Senate approval.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Murray Brewster/Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Anthony J. Tata withdrew his nomination to be the under secretary of defense for policy.

item.title: Private Boats Enter SpaceX Splashdown Area, Raising Concerns
item.description: “We need to do a better job next time” of securing the area, the NASA administrator, Jim Bridenstine, said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Bill Ingalls/NASA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: After the SpaceX capsule splashed down off the coast of Pensacola, Fla., private boats gathered in the area.

item.title: Scientists Worry About Political Influence Over Coronavirus Vaccine Project
item.description: Operation Warp Speed has moved along at a rapid clip. But some people involved in the process fear pressure to deliver an October surprise for President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Thomas, Noah Weiland, Peter Baker and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has been relentlessly promoting the administration’s vaccine efforts, including during an appearance at a biotechnology laboratory in North Carolina last week.

item.title: In St. Louis, Testing Liberal Might Against a Democratic Fixture
item.description: Cori Bush, an activist backed by the progressive group Justice Democrats, is trying to unseat 10-term Representative William Lacy Clay in a bid to turn protest-movement fervor into hard political power.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Michael B. Thomas for The New York Times
item.media:description: All over the country this summer, progressive candidates like Cori Bush are doing battle with veteran incumbents over the Democratic Party’s identity.

item.title: NASA Astronauts Safely Return to Earth: ‘Thank You for Flying SpaceX’
item.description: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley returned to Earth in the first water landing by an American space crew since 1975.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Bill Ingalls/NASA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: How Joe Arpaio’s Fate in Arizona Could Be a Window Into Trump’s
item.description: The polarizing former sheriff of Maricopa County, a stylistic doppelgänger to President Trump, is running for his old office in a state where approval of both men has slid.
item.dc:creator: Hank Stephenson
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Arpaio, the former sheriff of Maricopa County, is hoping to regain that office, and still pushing a hard-line message on immigration.

item.title: Relief Package Deal Remains Elusive as Impasse Over Jobless Benefits Persists
item.description: Negotiators acknowledged some progress over the weekend, but said they remained far apart on a number of issues.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, along with Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, speaking with reporters after a rare Saturday meeting to discuss a new coronavirus relief package.
